Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Story: I stood at the edge of the skate park, my phone buzzing in my pocket with texts from Jamie, my boyfriend, asking if I was on my way. It was our last weekend together before he left for his job overseas, and we’d planned a whole day just for us. But right in front of me, my little brother, Max, was strapping on his helmet, determined to try a new trick on the steepest, roughest ramp in the park. He looked at me, grinning, but I could see the nerves in his eyes. Mom always said to look out for him, and I knew if anything happened, I’d never forgive myself. Jamie’s messages grew more insistent—he wanted every minute we could get before his flight. My heart twisted as I watched Max wobble at the top of the ramp, while Jamie’s name flashed on my screen. I felt torn in two, desperate not to let either of them down, but knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
